title: Krum Arnaudov
text:
My skills are an intersection between Machine Learning, NLP (which people call AI nowadays) and Business administration. I am the core AI Architect of Ask FT.
Comfortable with Python, SQL and R. Experience with Google Cloud, AWS, Docker, Cloudera, Power BI, MicroStrategy.
Throughout my pre-ML carrier, I’ve done Data Science Consulting, Operations management, Process improvement, Key account management, Quality management, Coaching and Customer Support for living. I am in my wheelhouse building trust with customers and stakeholders, managing change and nurturing teams.

2018 – HP CS President Leading the Way Global Award

2019 – HP Amaze Global Award for “amazing contributions in both business impact and culture”

Happily married, proud father and husband.





Ask FT is a generative-AI assistant that answers subscriber questions by synthesising two decades of FT journalism.

Designed vector-search pipeline indexing >3 M articles dating back to 2004

Integrated Anthropic Claude 3 Haiku → Claude 3.5 Sonnet ensemble for answer generation and citation extraction

Built usage analytics & feedback loop that drives weekly model-instruction tuning

Championed model-agnostic architecture enabling rapid A/B testing with OpenAI, Mistral and Gemini family LLMs

Led closed-beta rollout to ≈500 FT Professional users; currently powering 10 k+ queries/day with 92 % helpfulness rating

Featured in The Verge, Voicebot.ai and the FT press release announcing the organisation’s first generative-AI tool.



FT Article Vectorisation [SentenceTransformers, Gensim, spaCy, Vetiver, FastAPI] - Transforming article text into numerical vectors to be used in downstream tasks such as semantic similarity, search and others.
FT Propensity to Renew [tidymodels, Rstudio Connect] - Building propensity-to-renew models per user cohort for the purposes of marketing campaigns.
Amplify Analytics Time Series Forecasting for more than 1500+ Series Forecasting daily patient registrations per patient cohorts for US hospitals.
Amplify Analytics Novelty Detection using GMM, One-Class SVM and IsolationForest Novelty Detection of medical claim rejections.
Amplify Analytics Medical claims outcome classification Medical claims outcome classification using XGBoost.





SEBRA playground mini-package to work with the Bulgarian government opendata SEBRA dataset.
articlevectorizer package to for creating text embeddings with a scikit-learn-style API. Basically, a worse embetter





Going far with open source tools in NLP Software University (softuni.bg), April 2023
What do we know about chatGPT? FT ML&Data Club, Feb 2023| Slides
Creating and assessing media article embeddings Sofia Data Science Society, Dec 2022| Github Repo and Slides
Creating letter embeddings - FT ML&Data Club, Oct 2022| Inspired by Vincent Warmerdam’s video on the same topic




Minor scikit-learn fixes and docs here, here and here
Minor sktime fix here

title: Reading list
text:
This will be an active reading list of videos, books, posts and more generally, anything that I intend to read. Some day.

The missing semester MIT - https://missing.csail.mit.edu/
FASTApi live coding - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_BZGtifh_gw&ab_channel=DeepLearningAI
Create your blog with Quarto - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xtSFXtDf4cM&ab_channel=PositPBC
Hamel and Radek on Quarto - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IqB-zVc5NgI&feature=youtu.be
Later in the year, either Statistical Rethinking 2023 (again), BayesRules! or Regression and other stories.
NLP with Transformers (in progress)
Pytorch learning:

Patrick’s Pytorch course - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EMXfZB8FVUA&list=PLqnslRFeH2UrcDBWF5mfPGpqQDSta6VK4&index=1&ab_channel=PatrickLoeber
https://www.learnpytorch.io/

Nils Reimers: Sentence Transformers, Search, Future of NLP | Learning from Machine Learning #3 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jOj4d3JNBDU&ab_channel=LearningfromMachineLearning

Similar - with James Briggs - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bzf1Xh3CLEM&ab_channel=Cohere with

On the new pandas internals - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIbYomIcl34&ab_channel=PyData
Posts on creating a search + Q&A:

Simon’s post with GTR-T5-Large - https://til.simonwillison.net/python/gtr-t5-large
Simon’s wrapper over openAI’s API - https://til.simonwillison.net/gpt3/chatgpt-api
Hamel’s post - https://github.com/hamelsmu/chat-langchain/
OpenAI’s notebook - https://github.com/openai/openai-cookbook
Sentence Transformers Example - https://www.sbert.net/examples/applications/semantic-search/README.html#examples

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Well, I will try blogging. I should have done this years ago, as with many other things, but better late than never.
I am trying to learn more ‘software-y’ aspects of the ML/DS world. This will help. This blog is built with quarto. Clever people like Hamel have built theirs using it. I am giving it a try as well. It worked (relatively) easily. I know enough markdown for this to be an easy starting path. The best lesson learnt so far - creating a website involves as much copying other great examples, as any other software activity. Need to learn more of the .css/.nojekyll elements. I will - in time. For now, this is good enough.
I intend to write mostly short “today I learned” or (TIL) posts. I learned about TILs from Vincent Warmerdam, who in turn has mentioned hearing about the idea from Simon Willison. I find it quite convenient. It gets you in the habit of writing down your thoughts, but in smaller bits. Trains you for long form posts. Helps with building a library of ideas/learnings.
I will also maintain an active Reading List. I currently have a repo on the topic, but an editable blog post seems more elegant.
